articles.title: From Long Shots to Legends: 5 Most Unlikely Sports Champions
articles.author: Jenny Cohen
articles.excerpt: There's nothing quite like rooting for the underdog and seeing them actually pull off a victory. Sometimes it's an upset in a tournament to move on to the next round or a real David vs. Goliath...
articles.content:
There's nothing quite like rooting for the underdog and seeing them actually pull off a victory. Sometimes it's an upset in a tournament to move on to the next round or a real David vs. Goliath moment, with the unlikely winner slaying a big name.
Those wins, however, are usually just a Cinderella team picking up a victory in the early rounds of a tournament without getting much further in later rounds. It's fun to watch while they last, but it was never likely they'd go all the way.
But what about those athletes who use their time in the spotlight to actually win it all? It's a rare occurrence, but these champions proved it could be done.
- U.S. Olympic Hockey Team (1980)
- Villanova Basketball (1985)
- Buster Douglas (1990)
- Indiana University Football (2026)
- Leicester City (2016)
U.S. Olympic Hockey Team (1980)
The 1980 Olympics were held in Lake Placid, New York, but home country advantage was not expected to be much help for the U.S. Olympic hockey team. The team was made up of young college players who faced their toughest game during the Winter Games against a strong Soviet team, with most of the players also part of the Soviet Union's Red Army.
So it was a real shock when the ragtag U.S. hockey team beat the Soviet machine in a game that has been called the Miracle on Ice. And while the game is considered one of the biggest upsets in sports, it wasn't a gold-medal-winning game for the team, as they had to beat Finland in the final game of the tournament to secure their unlikely gold medal.
Villanova Basketball (1985)
College basketball's annual March Madness tournament has produced plenty of Cinderella stories and unlikely upsets over the years, but those Cinderellas usually have their carriages turn back into pumpkins before a more likely champion is crowned.
That wasn't the case, however, in 1985 when Villanova faced Georgetown in the tournament's final game. Villanova was only an eight-seed team against the No. 1-seeded Hoyas, led by future NBA Hall of Famer Patrick Ewing. But the Wildcats prevailed, winning by only two points to secure the championship. The team is still the lowest seed to ever win that title.
Buster Douglas (1990)
Buster Douglas was facing a daunting fight in 1990 against heavyweight champion Mike Tyson. It was so bad that some casinos in Las Vegas decided not to take bets on the fight, assuming that it would be an easy win for Tyson, who had a 37-0 record.
Instead, Douglas took 10 rounds to knock out Tyson, stunning the boxing world. It also shocked Tyson, who was rumored to have been partying instead of training in the days leading up to the match, assuming it would be an easy win for him.
Indiana University Football (2026)
Indiana University's football team had been lovable losers for decades, with one of the worst winning percentages of any football team in the football bowl era. Then the team hired coach Curt Cignetti, who quickly turned the team into a winning powerhouse.
The Hoosiers went from perennial losers to a winning record and, in 2026, won the college football championship with an unbeaten 16-0 record. That's a pretty amazing turnaround for a team that was 3-9 three years earlier and hadn't made a bowl game in years.
Leicester City (2016)
Just how unlikely was Leicester City's Premier League championship in 2016? The team had 5000-to-1 odds that they could win the title in one of soccer's most important leagues.
But that's exactly what the team did, picking up the championship despite having one of the lowest-paid rosters in a league that favored highly financed teams with big names. The last time the team had seen any success close to that was a second-place finish in the Premier League, and that was in 1929.

articles.content:
Afghanistan Was a Crossroad of the Ancient World, Where Hellenistic Culture Blended With Buddhist Influences
Alexander the Great conquered the region around 329 B.C.E., leaving behind Greek and Macedonian settlers who intermarried with locals. Their descendants eventually formed new kingdoms whose legacies continue to be debated today
In 1961, the then-king of Afghanistan, Mohammed Zahir Shah, went hunting in the north of his country, on the border with Tajikistan. On a slab of sand called Ai-Khanoum, where two rivers straddle each other, he noticed something odd: the outlines of a city.
Zahir Shah quickly called in the French Archaeological Delegation in Afghanistan, which was formed in 1922 at the request of a previous Afghan king to study the country’s buried history. Although official accounts suggest that Zahir Shah was the first to stumble upon Ai-Khanoum, the ancient city’s existence had already been documented more than a century earlier.
Still, what the archaeologists found at the site astounded them. A gymnasium, a theater and an acropolis emerged from the dust. The scholars unearthed Corinthian column capitals, Hellenistic mosaics, and a massive silver disc depicting the goddesses Nike and Cybele in a chariot pulled by lions. More than 2,500 miles from Greece, they had uncovered a city that was clearly inspired by Hellenistic culture.
Need to know: What does “Hellenistic” mean?
- Derived from the ancient Greek word “Hellas” (a name for Greece), the term “Hellenistic” typically refers to the period spanning the death of Alexander the Great, in 323 B.C.E., to the death of Cleopatra VII, in 30 B.C.E.
- During this period, Greece wielded control over a vast empire that stretched across the Mediterranean and the Middle East. The blending of Greek and local traditions in these domains is now known as Hellenistic culture.
Ai-Khanoum is one remnant of the Greek-speaking kingdoms that once dominated Afghanistan. For centuries, Central Asia, also known by the ancient name Bactria, was where different cultures of the ancient world, from the Mediterranean to India and China, met and merged. At the center of it all were Greek-speaking rulers, some of whom were even early converts to Buddhism.
“In the minds of many historians, Central Asia is the periphery of the ancient world,” says Frank Lee Holt, a historian at the University of Houston who has spent decades studying the Greek presence in Central Asia. “I think it’s the center. Bactria was the hub for half the planet for centuries. Through Bactria, lapis lazuli made its way to the tomb of King Tut. It’s through Bactria that silk got to Rome. It’s through Bactria that Buddhism got to China. When you look at it properly, the center of the ancient world was Central Asia.”
Studying this ancient crossroad can be challenging. Today, Ai-Khanoum is in disrepair; satellite imagery shows holes dug by robbers pockmarking the site. French archaeologists fled the city following the Soviet Union’s invasion of Afghanistan in 1979, and since then, Ai-Khanoum has been exposed to looters, warfare and erosion, obscuring Greek history in the region.
Greek influences in Central Asia
That history starts with Alexander the Great, who marched through the area around 329 B.C.E. The conquering king left behind thousands of Greek and Macedonian settlers, often against their will. (As Holt writes in Into the Land of Bones: Alexander the Great in Afghanistan, many of these colonists were “no longer useful to him, because of age, injuries or dubious loyalty.”) Alexander’s successors, the Seleucids, who reigned in present-day Iran and Iraq, also sent fresh rounds of settlers to the area in the late fourth and early third centuries B.C.E. “Somehow enough Greeks settled in and married with the locals to create their own states,” says Holt.
The lands between present-day Iran and India eventually became the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom, established around 250 B.C.E., and the Indo-Greek Kingdom, which originated as an offshoot of a Greco-Bactrian dynasty at the turn of the third century B.C.E. Locals spoke Greek to some degree and were probably somewhat inspired by Hellenistic culture, scholars argue.
How important these kingdoms were, however, is a matter of debate compounded by a lack of sources. “We do know that they were a hub for the transmission of ideas and trade goods,” says Holt.
The Greco-Bactrians and the Indo-Greeks minted large quantities of coins, which are still treasured by antique dealers today. The largest surviving gold coin minted in the ancient world didn’t come from the Roman Empire or classical Greece. Instead, the nearly six-ounce 20-stater piece was commissioned by the Greco-Bactrian king Eucratides I in the mid-second century B.C.E. The largest silver coin from the ancient era bears the likeness of Amyntas Nicator, an Indo-Greek king who ruled in the first century C.E.
Both of these kingdoms fell within a century or two of their establishment. Eucratides was assassinated, possibly by one of his sons, around 145 B.C.E. Ai-Khanoum was abandoned around the same time. Migrations to the area caused political shocks, culminating in the end of states already weakened by internal wars and strife.
Some Greek influence persisted in the area afterward. “We have found objects, like a signet ring in northern Afghanistan, that have Greek inscriptions and an image of the Greek goddess of wisdom, Athena, on them,” says Holt. “So there is a continued transfer of cultural ideas.” The ring dates to the first century C.E., long after Ai-Khanoum was abandoned.
How Hellenistic culture shaped Gandharan Buddhism
One of the archaeologists uncovering Central Asia’s continued Hellenistic legacy is Luca M. Olivieri, of Ca’ Foscari University of Venice. Also the director of the Italian Archaeological Mission to Pakistan, he mainly works in the Swat Valley, on Pakistan’s northern border with Afghanistan.
Olivieri first visited Swat in 1987. In addition to excavating Indo-Greek ruins and early Buddhist artwork, he has lived through events most archaeologists will never experience. In late 2007, the Taliban seized the valley, forcing Olivieri and his Italian colleagues to flee. Olivieri was one of the first archaeologists to return after Pakistan’s army reconquered Swat in 2009.
On Olivieri’s first night back in Swat, locals approached him at the archaeological mission’s headquarters. “There was a deluge of stories,” he recalls. “They wanted to take all the tragic events out of their souls. Many Buddhist archaeological remains were damaged or left unattended. Some were intentionally destroyed.”
A central focus of Olivieri’s research is Gandharan Buddhism, a Buddhist culture that developed in what is today northern Pakistan and Afghanistan, in a region referred to as Gandhara in antiquity. Gandhara was a major center of Buddhism between roughly the third century B.C.E. and 1200 C.E.
Gandharan Buddhism, which was often concentrated in monasteries, shows Hellenistic influences, or “readaptations,” as Olivieri calls them. Greek and Buddhist intermixture was not new to the region. The Indo-Greek king Menander I Soter, who ruled in the second century B.C.E., for instance, reportedly converted to Buddhism after posing a series of philosophical questions to a senior monk.
A frequent scene depicted in Gandharan Buddhism is the Buddha wrestling with his companions. The manner in which he does so is almost identical to the “bear hug” wrestling move performed by the mythological hero Herakles (the Greek name for Hercules) in ancient sculptures. “This is a motif in Hellenistic art,” says Olivieri. “There, it represents a completely different story: the fight between Herakles and the giant Antaeus. In Gandhara, however, it shows us the Buddha, not Herakles.”
Robert DeCaroli, an art historian at George Mason University, echoes Oliveri’s assessment.
“The Buddhists in Gandhara found inspiration in Greek artistic styles,” DeCaroli says. “The Buddha looks very fit. He reflects the idea of the athlete, a type in Greek art. The Buddha looks like he just went to the gym.”
Realistic anatomy, a key feature of Greek art, also found its way into Gandharan depictions of Buddha. Then there’s the way the Buddha dresses. Some scholars argue that Gandharan Buddhas wear Greek- or Roman-style togas. DeCaroli says that might just be a coincidence because Buddhist monks dressed in a similar fashion. “Buddhas in Gandharan art cover both shoulders, compared to only one in images made further east,” he explains. “But that might just reflect the colder weather in Gandhara.”
Ordinary people in Gandharan art dress in Mediterranean fashion and sport Greek and Roman hairstyles. Depictions of Herakles, Athena and satyrs are plentiful. There are “many cultural connections,” says DeCaroli.
One of Greek culture’s most enduring influences on Buddhism is its emphasis on storytelling. “Ancient Greeks have a fondness for narratives,” says DeCaroli. “Some of the most complete visual depictions of the Buddha’s life hail from the Gandharan region.”
Stories of the Buddha’s life were shared and depicted across the Indian subcontinent during this period but never really unified into one overarching narrative. Gandharan Buddhism created art that featured large sequences of these tales, preserving valuable information for modern scholars. “We don’t know exactly why this is,” says DeCaroli. “It might reflect Greek and Roman theater traditions. It might have something to do with Hellenistic popular art forms. We are forced to speculate a bit. But it probably came from the Greeks.”
Colonialism’s legacy in Central Asia
However interesting this cultural intermixing is, its study remains marred by colonialism. Historians today don’t know very much about Greek communities in Central Asia. Hardly any contemporary texts survive, and archaeological excavations are limited by political instability and continued habitation of ancient sites. That’s why scholars rely heavily on artifacts such as coins.
In the absence of concrete information, colonizers’ imagination filled in the gaps in the historical record. “In the 19th century, Central Asia was picked apart and preyed upon by the British and Russian Empire[s],” says Rachel Mairs, a classicist at the University of Reading in England. “Both of these entities were interested in the notion of a Greek presence in the area. Both identified themselves with Greek and classical culture, which is why they politically appropriated the ancient Greek influences in the area.”
Colonizers often viewed historical Greek communities as the source of “civilization” in Central Asia. Mairs, however, downplays the importance of the Indo-Greeks and Greco-Bactrians, noting that because of a lack of sources, very few sweeping statements can be made about these kingdoms or Greek influence in Central Asia more generally.
Just because Indo-Greek and Greco-Bactrian rulers used Greek script in their writings, for example, that doesn’t necessarily mean these kings were descendants of Greek settlers, Mairs says. By today’s standards, they might not have even identified as ethnically Greek—a concept unfamiliar to ancient people. “Greekness” in antiquity was more often defined by use of the Greek language and the adoption of certain cultural beliefs and practices. It didn’t necessarily refer to ancestry. “We have to be careful” when making comparisons, Mairs cautions.
The same warning applies to Hellenistic influence on Buddhism. Gandharan Buddhism uses Hellenistic motifs, but their importance is unclear. “I often compare it to an Italian wearing blue jeans in the 1950s,” says Olivieri. “Did that mean that this was an American national or an individual that had absorbed the American culture as a whole? I would argue not. Blue jeans were simply in fashion at that time.”
Olivieri adds, “The same happened in the courts of Gandhara, the patrons of the Buddhist community. Hellenistic motifs and details were in vogue, and some were adopted and readapted after their meaning was transformed. The same images, although visually similar to their Hellenistic sources, would have been obscure for a Greek or Roman visitor.”
Even the famous archaeological site of Ai-Khanoum isn’t undeniably Greek. “Yes, there’s a gymnasium and acropolis,” Holt says. “But that city is also full of non-Greek elements. The temple architecture is not Greek at all. The houses don’t look anything like those of a typical Greek site. If you would transport Ai-Khanoum to Greece, it would have been considered a non-Greek city.”

Medieval Monks Wrote Over a Copy of an Ancient Star Catalog. Now, a Particle Accelerator is Revealing the Long-Lost Original Text
The parchments initially contained references to a star catalog and maps created during the second century B.C.E.
A little more than a thousand years ago, monks at Saint Catherine’s Monastery in Egypt’s Sinai desert removed Western Palestinian Aramaic and Greek writing from animal-skin parchments. They replaced the words with a Syriac translation of writings by John Climacus, also known as Saint John of the Ladder.
The monks had created something called a palimpsest—a text whose original writing was mostly erased to make room for new work—named the Codex Climaci Rescriptus. Parchments were extremely expensive at the time, so reusing pieces was common practice.
The original text, however, might not be completely lost. That’s good news, because it seems to contain copied portions of a second-century B.C.E. star catalog with maps originally created by the Greek astronomer Hipparchus, known as the “father of scientific astronomy.” Researchers are now using a type of particle accelerator at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory to uncover the hidden words.
“X-ray beams from our synchrotron at SLAC are helping uncover the long-erased and overwritten star map by scanning for trace metals left behind by the original inks,” reads a social media post from SLAC.
Previous work has revealed that many pages of the Codex Climaci Rescriptus come from a fifth- or sixth-century C.E. book, which included a copy of an astronomical poem titled Phaenomena. It was originally written by the Greek poet Aratus in the third century B.C.E. Alongside the poem appear to be transcriptions from Hipparchus’ star catalog, which was completed around 129 B.C.E. The work represents the “earliest known attempt to record accurate coordinates of many celestial objects observable with the naked eye,” researchers wrote in a 2022 study investigating the Codex Climaci Rescriptus’ original writings.
Little of Hipparchus’ work, which he likely documented on papyrus, has endured the test of time. So, researchers often rely on the writings of later authors to investigate the Greek astronomer. Some of his known stellar coordinates have reached modern-day scholars through a Latin translation of Aratus’ poems and related texts, according to the study.
Did you know? Hipparchus’ history
Hipparchus was born in Nicaea, which is located in modern-day Turkey. He made advancements in trigonometry and approached astronomy as a mathematical science. He spent much of his adult life observing the night sky and conducting research on the island of Rhodes in Greece.
Last month, researchers at SLAC began scanning 11 pages of the codex, which were sent to the laboratory in Menlo Park, California, by the Museum of the Bible in Washington, D.C., reports KQED’s Ayah Ali-Ahmad. The facility’s synchrotron lightsource instrument produces intense X-ray beams that can unveil the document’s hidden text based on the ink composition, which differs from that used by the monks. The work has already revealed the ancient Greek word for “Aquarius” and details about stars within the constellation, Victor Gysembergh, a historian of science at the French National Center for Scientific Research who is leading the project, tells the outlet.
“The goal is to recover as many of these coordinates as possible,” he says. “This will help us answer some of the biggest questions on the birth of science: Why did they start doing science 2,000 and more years ago? How did they get so good at it so fast? Because the coordinates we are finding are incredibly accurate for something that is done with the naked eye.”
The scribe who copied Phaenomena, which details how various constellations rise and set, onto the parchment integrated descriptions of the stars’ positions that were probably based on Hipparchus’ work. The celestial objects’ coordinate system and accuracy align with references to the ancient astronomer’s writings, reports Science News’ Adam Mann. “There’s an appendix which includes coordinates of the stars discussed in the poem, and then little sketches of the star maps,” Minhal Gardezi, a physicist at the University of Wisconsin–Madison who is working on the project, tells the outlet.
Bradley Schaefer, a historian of astronomy at Louisiana State University who isn’t involved in the work, tells Scientific American’s K. R. Callaway that the unveiled text might shed light on enduring questions on if later astronomers, including Ptolemy, were recording their own observations or partly assembling earlier work made by others.
“Who knows what the star chart study will show?” Graham George, a chemist at the University of Saskatchewan in Canada who also isn’t involved in the new research, says to Science News. “I can’t wait to find out.”

A Smithsonian magazine special report
Historians Thought This Rare Renaissance Portrait by One of the First Famous Female Artists Was Lost to History—Until It Surfaced in North Carolina
Sofonisba Anguissola’s 16th-century painting of a clergyman was known only through a black-and-white photo. However, the original had been hiding in a private collection in North Carolina since 1977
A long-lost painting by Sofonisba Anguissola—one of the few famous women artists of the Renaissance—has resurfaced in New York City. Her Portrait of a Canon Regular, painted in 1552, was recently displayed at the Winter Show, marking its first time on public view.
Portrait of a Canon Regular depicts an unidentified clergy member mid-lecture. His right hand touches the pages of a Bible, open to the Gospel of John. An eagle, a symbol of St. John, holds the book aloft in its talons, “hovering somewhat menacingly in the dark,” per a statement from Robert Simon Fine Art, the gallery that presented the piece.
Anguissola “worked with deeper study and greater grace than any woman of our times at problems of design,” wrote the 16th-century Renaissance artist and biographer Giorgio Vasari. “For not only has she learned to draw, paint and copy from nature, and reproduce most skillfully works by other artists, but she has on her own painted some most rare and beautiful paintings.”
Portrait of a Canon Regular made its debut at the Winter Show, an art fair held at the Park Avenue Armory on the Upper East Side. The painting was presented with a price tag of $450,000, reports Artnet’s Eileen Kinsella. According to the gallery, the canvas is one of fewer than 20 signed paintings by Anguissola that survive today.
Until recently, Portrait of a Canon Regular was thought to be lost. The Frick Art Reference Library had a black-and-white photo of it dated to the 1920s, but the trail stopped there, reports Artnet. Then, in 2024, art historian Michael Cole, author of the book Sofonisba’s Lesson, gave a lecture about Anguissola at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. The talk was posted on YouTube.
Fortunately, the owners of the original painting, based in Durham, North Carolina, watched the lecture. They had inherited the piece from their relatives, who had purchased it at a North Carolina auction in 1977.
“I was initially approached to value the painting and to consult on its conservation, provenance and proper framing,” art dealer Robert Simon tells Artnet. “In the end, the owners decided to sell the painting, and I am acting as their agent in bringing it to a wider audience.”
Anguissola was born in Cremona, Italy, around 1532. Encouraged by her father, she began artistic training as a teenager and quickly showed promise. Her early work was even praised by Michelangelo, who corresponded with her father. Anguissola painted Portrait of a Canon Regular when she was around 20; the portrait is her earliest signed and dated piece.
Fun fact: Sofonisba Anguissola’s early work
Michelangelo complimented Anguissola’s portrayal of a young child in Boy Bitten by a Crayfish (circa 1554), according to the National Museum of Women in the Arts.
By the late 1550s, Anguissola’s artistic reputation had extended beyond Italy. In 1559, the king of Spain, Philip II, asked her to be a lady-in-waiting to his third wife, Elisabeth of Valois. Anguissola lived in the Spanish court for 14 years, painting portraits of the royal family, teaching the queen to draw and caring for children. After marrying the brother of the Viceroy of Sicily, she moved to the Italian island, where she would live until her death in 1625.
“Sofonisba wasn’t just anybody,” Salvatore Patane, a Sicilian priest, told the London Times’ Julia Buckley in November 2025. Anguissola lived in Patane’s town, Paterno, which recently held a celebration of the artist. “She was a woman who managed to leave home and go to the most important court of the time,” he added.
Anguissola’s position in the Spanish court provided security and status, but its strict artistic standards tamped down her creativity, Simon tells the Art Newspaper’s Carlie Porterfield. “In Spain, every portrait had to look kind of alike, so she lost a lot of the inventiveness,” he says.
As such, Anguissola’s earlier work from Italy—“her brilliant portraits of the 1550s”—are highly valued, Simon tells Artnet. Per the Times, Vasari wrote that Anguissola’s portraits were “done so well that they appear to breathe.”
Anguissola produced many detailed portraits of herself, royals, nobles and several clergymen. On the desk before the subject of Portrait of a Canon Regular is a Turkish carpet, “a preferred device of the artist that is found in several variations in her works,” Simon tells Artnet. The portrait was recently conserved, revealing her full signature: “Sophonisba Anguissola Virgo,” followed by the date 1552.
Though Anguissola gained important recognition during her life, her artistic reputation faded over the centuries. Some of her works were misattributed. For a long time, Anguissola’s Juana of Austria and a Young Girl (1561-62) was credited to the Italian master Titian.
In recent decades, however, many exhibitions have been dedicated to Anguissola’s work. Per the National Gallery of Art, “She is increasingly recognized as one of the major figures of the later Italian Renaissance.”
“You can’t find a mediocre woman artist [from this time], as they would not have had a career, right?” Simon tells the Art Newspaper. “They had to be really good.”
